item.title: FoundationNET AI-Generated Notes
item.description:
The SCP Foundation, known for its secrecy and handling of anomalous phenomena, would likely design its private internet, or intranet, with an emphasis on security, redundancy, and compartmentalization to ensure that its global network of Foundation sites is isolated from public systems. Here's how the SCP Foundation might approach integrating a private internet across its sites:


Isolated from the Public Internet: The Foundation's network would be entirely isolated from the public internet to prevent any risk of data leaks, cyber-attacks, or external surveillance. Each site would only connect to the intranet via secure, private channels.
High-bandwidth Fiber Optic Backbone: The network would rely on a dedicated fiber optic backbone for high-speed, encrypted communications between sites. This infrastructure might use private satellite systems for remote locations (e.g., Area-51 type desert sites or oceanic installations).
Multiple Layers of Redundancy: To protect against physical damage or localized failures, the network would have multiple layers of redundancy, including alternate communication routes (e.g., satellite, dedicated microwave towers, or secure, underground cables) between key Foundation locations.


Strict Network Segmentation: The Foundation would segment its network into different layers based on clearance levels (e.g., Site Personnel, Mobile Task Forces, Researchers, and O5 Council). Each segment would have its own internal restrictions, preventing lower-clearance personnel from accessing sensitive or classified data.
Site-specific Firewalls: Every Foundation site would have its own set of highly secure firewalls, with data only being accessible on a need-to-know basis, even within the Foundation. The idea is that a breach at one site doesn't compromise others.
Compartmentalized Data Storage: Each site would store only the necessary data for its operations. Centralized, critical data (e.g., O5-level information) would be mirrored across multiple high-security locations with physical and digital protections in place.


End-to-End Encryption: All communication between Foundation sites would be encrypted using quantum-resistant algorithms to ensure that no data can be intercepted or decrypted by external actors.
Dynamic Encryption Algorithms: The Foundation would utilize self-changing encryption keys to protect against attempts to break the encryption. These keys would change regularly (e.g., every few seconds) to prevent anyone from gaining prolonged access.
Multi-factor Authentication (MFA): Access to the intranet and its resources would require multi-factor authentication, potentially integrating biometric scans (e.g., retina, DNA, or brainwave patterns) along with traditional methods like passwords or physical tokens.


Automated Monitoring Systems (AI-Driven): Advanced AI systems would constantly monitor network traffic for any anomalies, such as unauthorized access attempts, data exfiltration, or unusual communication patterns. The AI could also predict possible cyber-attacks based on historical data.
Intrusion Detection Systems (IDS): Each site would have an IDS in place to detect any unauthorized access attempts or hacking efforts. Once detected, these systems could activate immediate lockdown protocols to sever any suspicious communications or data transmissions.
Internal Auditing and Logging: All network activity would be logged for auditing purposes. These logs would be encrypted and stored in multiple secure locations, preventing tampering or unauthorized access. A special task force (e.g., a Mobile Task Force focused on digital security) might be assigned to investigate any irregularities.


Foundation-only Secure Messaging Systems: A private, secure messaging system would be in place for Foundation personnel, including encrypted emails, voice calls, and video conferencing that run entirely over the internal network.
Air-gapped Backup Systems: Sensitive information might be backed up to systems that are physically disconnected (air-gapped) from any network. These backups could only be accessed manually in secure facilities, making it virtually impossible for outside attackers to breach these systems remotely.


Anomaly-based Security: The SCP Foundation might use its own SCPs or anomalous technology to further secure the intranet. For example, SCPs capable of controlling electromagnetic waves could be used to cloak or disrupt unauthorized access attempts, while others might act as guardians, monitoring data in ways conventional systems cannot.
Memetic Hazards and Infohazards: Certain high-level security features might involve the use of memetic or infohazardous defenses, where unauthorized access to specific data triggers mind-affecting phenomena that neutralize or disorient the intruder.


Localized Servers with Autonomous Operations: Each site would be able to operate autonomously in case of a connection loss to the main network. Critical systems would continue functioning even in isolated states, reducing reliance on centralized data flows.
Data Purge Protocols: In case of a site breach, data purge protocols would be automatically activated, wiping sensitive information or transferring it to a secure off-site backup before it falls into enemy hands.


Adaptive Networking for Mobile Sites: The Foundation’s intranet would likely be designed to support mobile and hidden sites, such as temporary research outposts or Mobile Task Force headquarters. These would securely connect to the intranet when deployed, using encrypted, temporary connections like secure VPNs or encrypted satellite uplinks.
Containment of Digital Anomalies: Digital anomalies or SCPs that can exist in or affect digital networks would have specialized containment systems within the intranet. These would be closed networks isolated from the main systems but would allow for the study and containment of these anomalies without risking exposure to the rest of the Foundation's data.


Network-wide Lockdowns: In the event of a major breach, a complete lockdown of the intranet could be triggered remotely by high-level personnel, cutting off all communication between sites to contain the threat. During this time, individual sites would continue to operate using localized intranets.
Failsafe Devices: Each Foundation site might have a failsafe device capable of destroying sensitive hardware in the event of an extreme emergency, ensuring that no critical information falls into the wrong hands.


Specialized Research and Communication Channels: Given the multi-disciplinary nature of the Foundation, different departments (e.g., medical, research, security) would have their own dedicated channels on the intranet for collaboration. These channels would be carefully monitored and encrypted to ensure information doesn't cross into unauthorized areas.
Automated Software Patching and Updates: The Foundation would likely employ a system that automatically patches and updates its software and network protocols to protect against emerging threats without requiring downtime.
By employing these advanced and multi-layered approaches, the SCP Foundation would create a highly secure, resilient, and efficient private internet capable of supporting its global operations while keeping its secrets from both internal and external threats.
item.guid: Metabuilding/Notes & Drafts/FoundationNET AI-Generated Notes.md
item.dc:creator: Ace

item.title: Example 1
item.description:
I. Introduction

Purpose and scope of the handbook
Overview of the SCP Foundation's mission and objectives
Confidentiality and non-disclosure agreements
II. Organization Structure
Foundation hierarchy and chain of command
Departmental overview (e.g., Research, Security, Logistics)
Key personnel and contact information
III. Security Protocols
Clearance levels and access restrictions
Secure communication procedures (e.g., encrypted channels, need-to-know basis)
Emergency response procedures (e.g., containment breaches, site lockdowns)
IV. SCP Handling and Containment
Procedures for interacting with and handling SCP objects
Containment protocols and standard operating procedures (SOPs)
Safety precautions and personal protective equipment (PPE)
V. Research and Experimentation
Guidelines for conducting experiments on SCP objects
Approval processes for research proposals
Collaboration with other Foundation departments and external organizations
VI. Personnel Conduct and Responsibilities
Code of conduct and professional standards
Confidentiality and information security
Reporting requirements (e.g., incident reports, anomalies)
VII. Training and Development
Mandatory training programs (e.g., SCP handling, emergency response)
Continuing education and professional development opportunities
Mentorship programs
VIII. Benefits and Support
Compensation and benefits packages
Mental health resources and support services
Employee assistance programs (e.g., counseling, stress management)
IX. Disciplinary Actions and Termination
Procedures for addressing misconduct and policy violations
Disciplinary actions and penalties
Termination procedures and post-employment obligations
X. Appendices
Glossary of Foundation terminology
List of essential documents and resources (e.g., SCP classification guide, emergency contact information)
Map of Foundation facilities and sites


Security Protocols and Safety Measures
Overview of security clearances
Accessing classified information
Emergency response protocols
Containment breaches
Lockdowns and evacuations
Site-specific emergency procedures
Health and safety protocols
Protective equipment
Hazardous materials handling
Medical monitoring and wellness checks
Psychological evaluation and support programs
Containment Procedures
Definition and purpose of containment
Secure, Contain, Protect (SCP) - What this means in practice
Containment cell protocols
Routine inspections and maintenance
Reporting containment failures
Interaction with anomalies
Approved personnel and access restrictions
Anomaly research procedures
Ethics and handling of sentient SCPs
Research and Development
Research divisions and their purposes
Safe and ethical testing practices
Innovation and containment upgrades
Collaboration between departments
Field Operations
Mobile Task Forces (MTF) overview
Field agent protocols
Infiltration and investigation procedures
Retrieval of anomalies
Neutralizing or securing hostile anomalies
Risk and debriefing after field missions
Emergency containment and neutralization efforts
Personnel Management and Conduct
Employee code of conduct
Disciplinary actions and procedures
Harassment and workplace behavior policy
Performance reviews and promotion criteria
Reporting concerns, misconduct, or unethical behavior
Ethics and Compliance
Role of the Ethics Committee
Ethical guidelines for research, containment, and interaction
Compliance with local and international laws
Handling moral dilemmas
Employee Benefits and Resources
Compensation and insurance
Retirement and pensions
Leave policies: vacation, sick leave, and mental health days
On-site amenities and support services
Housing and recreation
Cafeteria and nutrition
Employee assistance programs (EAPs)
Educational and professional development opportunities
End of Employment Protocols
Voluntary resignation procedures
Retirement processes
Involuntary termination
Amnestic administration upon leaving
Security clearance revocation and confidentiality obligations
Appendices and Additional Resources
Glossary of terms and acronyms
List of common SCP classifications
Useful contacts (HR, Ethics Committee, Security, etc.)
Further reading: Foundation research papers, internal reports
item.guid: Metabuilding/Notes & Drafts/Handbook Outline Samples (AI Gen).md
item.dc:creator: Ace

item.title: Rank Order, Role Eligibility, Clearance Levels and Information Classifications
item.description:
Clearance levels and information classifications are two of the many ways the foundation maintains operational security in an outside of Foundation sites. They ensure that the right people have access to the right information at the right times. For example, a janitorial staff member would have the clearance level "0", which is the lowest level, granting him minimal access to locations within a facility, and this clearance comes with an information clearance of "Internal", which means he would have access to any information rated as "Internal".


Class D - Disposable personnel - No access to any zones. Must be escorted throughout entire facility. No information clearance granted at this "level". Sanitization procedure required monthly.
Level 0 - Blind Personnel - Access to most non-containment areas. Navigating in containment areas requires prior approval and escort. Grants "Internal" information clearance - (Must complete orientation module)
Janitorial Staff
Food services
General office staff/assistants (B&F) (Eligible for "Secret" information clearance on case/case basis)
Level 1 - Need-to-know basis personnel - Access to non-containment areas and LS containment zones (NOT containment chambers without prior approval and escort). Grants "Internal" information clearance. Eligible to receive "Secret" information clearance via membership to division or group - (Must complete information privacy module & department specific module)
Medical staff
Engineering & Technical
Scientific staff
Level 2 - Informed personnel - Access to non-containment areas and LS, MS containment zones. Grants "Secret" information clearance. Eligible to receive "Classified" information clearance via division or group ranking alongside giving escorts - (Must complete history module)
Foundation Integration
Security Department
Ethics Committee
Research & Development
Mobile Task Force(s)
Level 3 - Secret personnel - Access to non-containment areas, LS, MS, HS containment zones, and select restricted access zones. Grants "Classified" information clearance. Eligible to receive "Restricted" information clearance for select information. Can increase/decrease personnel clearance levels from zero through two with prior written approval from department head and/or site administration.
Internal Affairs/Human Resources
Level 4 - Classified personnel -
Department administrators
Level 5 - Restricted personnel - Eligible for Omni (full (select sites) site) access.
Foundation & site administration
Site director
item.guid: Metabuilding/Notes & Drafts/Rank Order, Role Eligibility, Clearance Levels and Information Classifications.md
item.dc:creator: Ace

item.title: Foundation Document Viewer // Contextual Amnestics Policy
item.description:
Believe it or not, you've most likely read this before (hence the vague déjà-vu)! This is The Foundation's policy on Contextual Amnestics and the therapy that is typically associated with it. This can be a little disorienting, and that is completely normal. This is why we believe that the most accepted approach to the recent exposure to amnestics is to deliver this policy in a friendly way each and every time. Typically, the amnestics exposure video is shown in place of this text, but in cases where the video is unavailable, this is what is showed. Now, outward and onward to the policy at hand.

To get an idea of what amnestics, let alone contextual amnestics, is, we must first dive into the ship-in-a-bottle that is the human mind. A vast and expansive place, the human mind houses the seat of consciousness with its subsequent areas of memory and cognition. As you may have guessed, your work anywhere, let alone here, requires a functioning memory. We mean, think about it, without a memory, you wouldn't be able to remember how to walk, or add numbers, or even exist! Memory is but one facet of the conscious experience and a necessary evil that The Foundation must address.

Memory is something complex, and but a yin of the yin-yang of consciousness. We, in the past, have had to wipe out entire chunks of memory in the process of delivering amnestics, but this is not the reality we face today. This is why you may feel a gap in between your conscious experience and memory. You may feel a fuzziness where a memory we have deemed too critical once was. You may poke and prod at it all you want, but there is simply fresh neural growth there, and it will soon be reassigned as a new memory. Don't be alarmed though, as the procedure was painless, and the procedure has been done countless times on employees just like you! For obvious reasons, you are not permitted to know the process in which we address the "deletion" of memories, but do know that the memories are safe with us!

The Foundation employs the use of amnestics to maintain the S.C.P. triad and more importantly, to maintain your own status quo. You most likely saw something you were not meant to see, such as a confusing object, or a devious individual, and the fact you saw whatever it was you saw warranted the alteration of your memories. It is in your best interest that we did as exposure to such things can cause, and is not limited to:

PTSD
Anxiety
Paranoia
High blood pressure
Heart attack
Stroke
Irreversible brain damage
Irreversible bodily harm
Death
Administering amnestics ensures that the exposure to something you were not meant to be exposed to does not affect your current or future work here at The Foundation.

During your exposure to the amnestics, you underwent what is known as Contextual Amnestics Therapy, or CAT for short. CAT is the catalyst which allows us to precisely pick what memories are altered. Think of it like an eye dropping of paint compared to our old method of pouring the whole bucket of paint over the memory. But your feeling woozy, uneasy, and possibly annoyed, and like we understood before, this is normal! Your local site's medical department has the solution to these discomforts. A specialized blend of cognitive pain relievers that will alleviate anxiety and stress. We will taper you off after 2 days, and you will adhere to the dosage schedule as you've agreed to in your Medical Treatment Consent Form.

If you still have questions, you can refer to your sites human resources agent who will answer to the best of their ability any questions you may have. In addition, feel free to reach out to your site's therapeutic liaison.
item.guid: The Foundation/Library & Archives/Policy & Procedures/Contextual Amnestics Policy.md
item.dc:creator: Ace

item.title: Foundation Document Viewer // FoundationNET Policy
item.description: The FoundationNET private internet is a solution that has been in the works for many years. Starting alongside the birth of the mainstream internet, The Foundation was quick to adopt some of the ideas that were laid out in the original ARPANET project. The Foundation was reliant on old methods of communication, and having a strong network backbone was essential for the foundation to progress. Using protocols and procedures found in the TOR network, The FoundationNET was conceived.
item.guid: The Foundation/Library & Archives/Policy & Procedures/FoundationNET Policy.md
item.dc:creator: Ace

item.dc:creator: Ace

item.title: Foundation Document Viewer // Radio Usage Procedure
item.description:
The standard issue radio for Foundation personnel is the APX NEXT All-Band P25 [smart] Radio, modified to meet the Foundation's strict security standards on data transmission through digital means. It offers multiple features such as a touch display, analog transmission buttons & channel dial, built in BLE+WiFi, and it is capable of broadcasting personnel status to a central server. General usage is straightforward. The unit is comprised of a digital touch screen and analog buttons for transmission, which means usage is streamlined and accessible for a variety of use cases.
General setup instructions are as follows:

Provision and register for a radio. (This is done by filing a Personal Radio Request Form through the Engineering & Technical Department)
Receive and turn on your radio, ensuring it has been properly configured
Set your status and location as needed
Dial the analog knob to your desired channel and press it in to register that channel. Press it in twice to unregister the channel. You can register up to 3 channels, and you will hear broadcasts from those three channels.
Press the side button in once to transmit. Press it in three times to send a notification ping to other radios on the same channel.
Press and hold the side button for 10 seconds, or alternatively, press and hold the side button, then tap the on-screen indicator three times to send out a distress ping to all radios regardless of channel (this will transmit your name and location).
Note For specific radio configuration, refer to your department head, division head, or otherwise primary point of contact for your assignment.

The following radio codes apply to the following departments, alongside the channel they operate on. They are used when communicating inter and intra departmentally. Each channel is accessible as determined by your department membership. This is defined when you first register for your radio.

Security Department (Ch. 01)
Mobile Task Forces (all except Alpha-1 (Uses restricted Ch. 99)) (Ch. 02)
Scientific Department (Ch. 03)
Engineering & Technical (Ch. 04)
Misc. Staff (janitorial branch of E&T) (Ch. 05)
Ch. 0 is used for site-wide communications (default channel when no channel is selected)
Note Channel 99 is not only restricted to Alpha 1, but it requires a passcode every time you register the channel. The passcode is changed in accordance to the credential rotation and recycling policy as stated in the Information Security Policy
item.guid: The Foundation/Library & Archives/Policy & Procedures/Radio Usage Procedure.md
item.dc:creator: Ace

item.title: Foundation Access Terminal // !Ext. User! // SCP Database
item.description:
While the entries may feel confusing, and the terminology a bit esoteric, understanding the format of these database entries are simple. Lets break it down starting from the top, with the Anomaly Classification System.
The ACS in detail is broken down here, but the simple components are as follows, rendered in a print-friendly format on the document:

The anomaly identification (SCP-XX-XXX)
The anomalies clearance level
The anomalies containment class and secondary containment class if applicable
The anomalies disruption class
Next in an SCP file is a short description of the anomaly and its effects.
In addition to this, a brief history of the anomaly is given, such as its first encounter, and other relevant historical context.
Then, the anomalies specialized containment procedures are described in detail. This includes its physical containment requirements, and any additional requirements for its containment environment.
Finally, any relevant appendices are listed in this order:

Testing policy appendix
Testing report(s) appendi(-x,-ces)
Initial encounter report appendix
Incident report(s) appendi(-x, -ces)
Additional appendices not already listed
item.guid: The Foundation/Library & Archives/SCP Files/SCP File Database.md
item.dc:creator: Ace

item.title: Item Inventory // Personnel Identity & Access Card
item.description: The Personnel Identity & Access Card is the gateway to access and authentication within The Foundation and its Sites. It acts not only as a form of identity, but it ties a Foundation employee to an IAM entity. This enables the card to be used at Foundation sites for physical access restrictions and allowances, network authentication, and even as a way to pay within Foundation sites.
item.guid: The Foundation/Objects, Things, & Stuff/Foundation Inventory/Personnel Identity & Access Card.md
item.dc:creator: Ace

item.title: Department Dossier // Internal Affairs Department
item.description: The Internal Affairs department is the department that focuses on the internal workings of The Foundation. It's goal is to ensure that the policies and procedures laid out by the Ethics Committee are being practiced as stated, and that no person deviates from them. They also handle any internal matters such as non-compliant, rogue, or otherwise personnel that pose a risk to The Foundation's S.C.P. triad.
item.guid: The Foundation/Structure, Clearance, and Hierarchy/Departments & Divisions/Internal Affairs Department.md
item.dc:creator: Ace

item.title: Department Dossier // Medical Department
item.guid: The Foundation/Structure, Clearance, and Hierarchy/Departments & Divisions/Medical Department.md
item.dc:creator: Ace

item.title: Department Dossier // O5 Council
item.description:
The O5 council is the board of directors for the foundation, which means that it oversees the direction and strategies for The Foundation. Each council-member directs one or more of the Foundations departments, and the assignment of a council-member to a department is typically self made. The O5 council meets regularly to discuss internal matters and happenings regarding The Foundation, its operations, and its sites. Any votes cast out by one of the members must be agreed upon unanimously, with any non-unanimous vote being left for The Administrator.


The O5 council is organized such that each council-member gets a say in The Foundations direction. This is done either directly, by influencing the department(s) that they lead, or indirectly through proposing changes that would affect Foundation Sites, other departments, or Foundation operations.
The council is made up of ten councilmen, formatted by the nomenclature, O5-X, where X is their designation. The order of the numbers does not necessarily define importance or status within the council. Instead it defines the chronological history of each member, with O5-1 being the longest standing member, and O5-10 being the newest member.
Each council-member controls a different department within The Foundation. In brief, the breakdown of who is in charge of what is described below:

Internal Affairs Department (O5-1 "The Watcher")
The Mobile Task Forces (O5-2 "Knight")
Scientific Department (O5-3 "The Curious Cat")
Ethics Committee (O5-4 "Yin-yang")
Medical Department (O5-5 "Healing Hands")
Security Department (O5-6 "Shining Armor")
Engineering & Technical Department (O5-7 "Toolbox")
Business & Finance Department (O5-8 "The Prodigy")
Foundation Integration Department (O5-9 "The Nosy One")
Research & Development Department (O5-10 "Intuitiveness")

item.title: Personnel Dossier // The Administrator
item.description: The Administrator is the primary governing unit of The Foundation. It is the lead body of the O5 Council and all proposals made by the O5 Council are vetted and approved by The Administrator. The Administrator cannot make decisions on its own. Instead, The Administrator is the final vote when unanimous decisions cannot be made by the O5 council, acting as a tiebreaker.
item.guid: The Foundation/Structure, Clearance, and Hierarchy/People of The Foundation/The Administrator.md
item.dc:creator: Ace

item.title: Foundation Access Terminal // !Ext. User! // Role Eligibility & Clearance Levels
item.description: Maintaining secrecy and security is a vital part of The Foundation's operations.
item.guid: The Foundation/Structure, Clearance, and Hierarchy/Role Eligibility & Clearance Levels.md
item.dc:creator: Ace

item.title: Foundation Access Terminal // !Ext. User! // The Foundation Departments
item.description: The Foundation utilizes its different departments for different reasons. However, the departments work together ultimately to maintain the S.C.P. Triad and to ensure the smooth execution of the Secure Contain Protect procedures. Each department is just as important as the next (and yes, janitors matter just as much as The Administrator here at The Foundation!).
item.guid: The Foundation/Structure, Clearance, and Hierarchy/The Departments of The Foundation.md
item.dc:creator: Ace

item.title: Foundation Access Terminal // !Ext. User! // The People of The Foundation
item.description: The Foundation employs a wide variety of people from places across the globe. Some of The Foundation's top scientists were Harvard graduates, and most of the Mobile Task Forces are filled with members who have graduated from west point, and were on their way to become the next five-star generals.
item.guid: The Foundation/Structure, Clearance, and Hierarchy/The People of The Foundation.md
item.dc:creator: Ace

item.title: Foundation Access Terminal // !Ext. User! // The Foundation Homepage
item.description:
The Foundation, colloquially known as The S.C.P. Foundation, is the covert NGO that is tasked with the goal of securing, containing, and protecting anomalies across the world. It does this through a three-pronged approach known as the S.C.P. triad. By practicing this methodology, The Foundation ensures that the public is safe from threats beyond understanding.

To better understand The Foundation of today, it is important to look at The Foundation of the past. The Foundation started as a goal driven idea that humanity doesn't have to live in fear of the anomalous, but instead live in peace under the assumption that the anomalous doesn't exist. The concept that the anomalous exists in the dark means that humanity can live in the light, and The Foundation is how that dynamic can exist. To understand the past of The Foundation is to understand The Administrator.

The Administrator is the ultimate governing unit of The Foundation, and its mere existence is debated in even the highest ranks of The Foundation. Rumored to be many things, there are a few truths for the Administrator, at least we think:

The Administrator is not a typical conscious entity; This means it may not even be human
The Administrator travels a lot, it is never in the same place for more than 12 hours
Anyone who comes in contact with the Administrator directly is administered contextual amnestics therapy after the interaction or is terminated
The Administrator prefers to deliver information through proxies, I.e passing letters, messages, or rarely digital media through the O5 council as its preferred proxy
The Administrator is barred from authoring any official Foundation content. This was decided by the O5 council in conjunction with the Administrator shortly after the formation of the first mobile task force
The Administrator leaves its subjects feeling at ease, but with a persistent feeling of subliminal dread after any interactions with others, even after CAT is administered
The Administrator isn't an... anomaly?

An anomaly is defined by The Foundation as: "An object, entity, concept, or idea that exerts non-traditional effects on its environment either directly or indirectly." The Foundation works to ultimately protect the status quo from these anomalies. The status quo is akin to the peace of the universe. If the status quo is disturbed, The Foundation believes that the cause must be contained to prevent future disruptions.

The three pillars of The Foundation are:

Security
To Secure anomalies that pose a threat to the status quo
Containment
To Contain anomalies in appropriate locations as to prevent future disruption to the status quo
Protection
To protect the status quo from the anomalies indefinitely
These pillars exist in three states, with the third already defined above. The pillars exist as principals, values, and most importantly, goals.
Note This is elaborated on further in the S.C.P. triad portion of the Foundation Employee Handbook.

The process of securing, containing, and protecting an anomaly sounds simple at first, but in actuality, is just as complex as some of the anomalies The Foundation works with. The process in its simplest form can be broken down into these seven steps.

An anomaly is identified out in the wild
An anomaly is verified to be anomalous
Current disruption caused by the anomaly is assessed while a specialized team known as a Mobile Task Force is assembled and dispatched to stake out the anomaly
At this point, the anomaly's initial containment needs are unknown, and the task force assigned is responsible for compiling the initial encounter report
Anyone who has had contact with the anomaly is either administered contextual amnestics therapy, or is terminated. CAT is attempted first, with termination having other difficulties associated with it
Said specialized team is either assigned for initial containment, merged or appended with another task force and its members, or reassigned entirely
At this point, the anomaly's initial containment needs are vaguely understood, so an initial containment attempt can happen at this point. There has to be a delicate balance between how long the task force waits to perform its initial containment attempt
If containment is successful, the flow continues, if it isn't, the task force must reattempt their containment attempt up to 3 times maximum, or consider alternative containment methods
The anomaly is housed at a temporary containment facility, typically the nearest Alpha level site, and research begins immediately on the anomaly
Research determines its specialized containment procedures, and whether the anomaly is appropriate for the current site (typically anomalies are relocated after the first 3-5 research sessions)
The anomaly either is assigned a permanent containment location, or one is constructed for it if the existing locations are inadequate. An SCP file is created for it which details its description, history, specialized containment procedures, and any tests, incidents, or other relevant info as appendices to said file
Regular assessment and testing must be performed to ensure the anomaly remains in its most dormant state, and that none of its anomalous properties have changed. Either way, any tests conducted must be appended to the anomalies SCP file
Note This is elaborated on further in the Secure Contain and Protect Procedure

The Foundation has many homes, and these places are known as the Foundation sites or Foundation outposts. They serve many purposes for the foundation and each location is typically unique.

Foundation Sites are the primary containment locations for anomalous entities, housing for Foundation personnel, and some are equipped to house disposable class personnel. They are indexed through a basic classification system which designates their location, series, and identification number.

Foundation outposts are locations typically overseen by either a Mobile Task Force or a division of the integration department. They do not contain any anomalous entities and most are anonymized through the use of fronts and shells. They are used for reconnaissance and forward operation purposes.
Note See more about foundation sites and outposts here.

The Foundation is just as much as a living entity as any other human, and it comes with many arms and legs. These arms and legs are the multiple departments within The Foundation. They serve many purposes for The Foundation and each has a specialized focus. The departments found in The Foundation and the corresponding department head are listed below:

O5 Council (The Administrator)
Internal Affairs Department (O5-1 "The Watcher")
The Mobile Task Forces (O5-2 "Knight")
Scientific Department (O5-3 "The Curious Cat")
Ethics Committee (O5-4 "Yin-yang")
Medical Department (O5-5 "Healing Hands")
Security Department (O5-6 "Shining Armor")
Engineering & Technical Department (O5-7 "Toolbox")
Business & Finance Department (O5-8 "The Prodigy")
Foundation Integration Department (O5-9 "The Nosy One")
Research & Development Department (O5-10 "Intuitiveness")
Note To see the divisions and groups within each department and an overview of that departments operations, checkout each department's page.
To see what each department does in brief, checkout the departments overview.

The Foundation has a dark future ahead of it. Not dark in the sense that the future for The Foundation is grim, but that The Foundation has only scratched the surface of an endless expanse of anomalous entities, objects, and concepts. The Foundation is believed to have uncovered only 5-7% of the anomalies that exist in the universe. For The Foundation to continue to secure, contain, and protect, it must remain vigilant against the forces that work against it, both anomalous and normal alike.
item.guid: The Foundation/The Foundation.md
item.dc:creator: Ace

item.title: Homepage of the Published SCP-NGU
item.description:
Hello! You've found the homepage of the SCP Next Generation Universe! This is a filler page to ensure compatibility with exporting the vault and publishing it to GitHub pages. It has nothing further to offer.
Head on over to The SCP-Next-Generation Universe to get started!
item.guid: index.md
item.dc:creator: Ace

item.title: Welcome to the SCP-NGU
item.description:
This is the homepage for the SCP-NGU, a massive passion project I've been working on for about a year now. It is an independent canon of the SCP universe based off of the general theme of the SCP universe. The difference is that it is a singular canon, not a shared one. This means that there are some things which are not flexible, such as task forces. In the SCP-NGU, there is a set amount of task forces and none can be added or removed freely without consequence. It is not meant to be modular, but instead serve as a base on which other creative works can be formed on top of.
Warning This is an active WORK-IN-PROGRESS at the time of reading! Sections are incomplete and/or entirely missing! I will not be taking pull requests, and suggestions aren't recommended except for grammar and continuity! I do appreciate them, and will acknowledge them, but there is no guarantee that any get implemented. Info This is a remake of my original SCP-NGU project. It is no longer publicly available, but a copy can be provided if you ask
The vault is organized in a casual way with a new employee feeling, but with the same level of detail you would expect in the places it would be appropriate in such as internal policies. You'll feel as though your an existing employee learning about The Foundation.
Note Prior experience with the SCP universe is not required, as the content in this vault is technically original content, and the content is not a continuation, but a singular canonical rewrite of the existing multi-canon universe.
Feel free to explore this vault at your own pace, or follow one of the links below to get you into the action quick:
item.guid: The SCP-Next-Generation Universe.md
item.dc:creator: Ace
